Item.Question: Derivative of sin(x)
Item.Answer: cos(x)

Item.Question: Derivative of cos(x)
Item.Answer: -sin(x)

Item.Question: Derivative of tan(x)
Item.Answer: sec(^2)(x)

Item.Question: Antiderivative of cos(x)
Item.Answer: sin(x)

Item.Question: Antiderivative of -sin(x)
Item.Answer: cos(x)

Item.Question: Antiderivative of sec(^2)(x)
Item.Answer: tan(x)

Item.Question: Product Rule

Item.heading: Theodore Sturgeon's 3 perspectives
Item.Question: What are Theodore Sturgeon's 3 perspectives?
Item.Answer: Biological Perspective, Historical Perspective, Cosmic Perspective

Item.heading: Theodore Sturgeon's 3 perspectives
Item.Question: Biological Perspective
Item.Answer: Ponders key events in one's own lifetime. Instinctual.

Item.heading: Theodore Sturgeon's 3 perspectives
Item.Question: Historical Perspective
Item.Answer: Ponders key events throughout recorded human history. Learned.

Item.heading: Theodore Sturgeon's 3 perspectives
Item.Question: Cosmic Perspective
Item.Answer: Ponders key events throughout all space & time

Item.heading: 3 Scales of Existence
Item.Question: What are the 3 Scales of Existence?
Item.Answer: Star System, Galaxy, Universe

Item.heading: Theodore Sturgeon's 3 perspectives
Item.Question: Star System
Item.Answer: Example: our solar system has 1 star (the sun), size = approx. 12 light-hours, age approx. 4.5 billion years

Item.heading: Theodore Sturgeon's 3 perspectives
Item.Question: Galaxy
Item.Answer: Example: our galaxy has 100 billion stars in a whirlpool, size = approx. 100,000 light-years, age approx. 13 billion years.

Item.heading: Time Units
Item.Question: Universe (3SE)
Item.Answer: All of space (billions of galaxies). Visible size is more than 28 billion light-years. Age = approx. 14 billion years.

Item.heading: Time Units
Item.Question: Which time units are based on precise measurement of the sky?
Item.Answer: Day and year

Item.heading: Time Units
Item.Question: How long is a year measured by th orbit of the Earth?
Item.Answer: 365.25 days

Item.heading: Time Units
Item.Question: How long is one sidereal day?
Item.Answer: 23 hours, 56 minutes

Item.heading: Time Units
Item.Question: What does sidereal mean?
Item.Answer: With respect to the stars.

Item.heading: Earth
Item.Question: Why are there seasons on Earth?
Item.Answer: Because of its tilt of 23.5 degrees spin axis and its elliptical orbit around the sun with.

Item.heading: Celestial Sphere
Item.Question: What is the Ecliptic?
Item.Answer: The apparent path of the sun over a year.

Item.heading: Celestial Sphere
Item.Question: What is the plane of the Earth's orbit?
Item.Answer: The Ecliptic of the Celestial Sphere.

Item.heading: Celestial Sphere
Item.Question: Where do eclipses occur?
Item.Answer: In the ecliptic plane when the sun, moon, and Earth align.

Item.heading: Celestial Sphere
Item.Question: What units do you use to measure positions on the celestial sphere?
Item.Answer: Angels: degree, Arc-minute ('), Arc-Second (")

Item.heading: Celestial Sphere
Item.Question: How many arc-minutes is 1 degree?
Item.Answer: 1 degree equals 60 arc-minutes (60')

Item.heading: Celestial Sphere
Item.Question: How many arc-seconds are in one arc-minute?
Item.Answer: 1 arc-minute (60') equals 60 arc-seconds (60")

Item.heading: Phases of the Moon
Item.Question: What are the phases of the moon?
Item.Answer: New moon, waxing (growing) crescent, first quarter, waxing gibbous, full moon, waning (decrease in visible surface area) gibbous, third quarter, waning crescent

Item.heading: Moon
Item.Question: True or False: The moon always has same side facing the Earth
Item.Answer: True: The moon always has the same side facing the Earth.

Item.heading: Moon
Item.Question: Define the "Spin Period" of the moon.
Item.Answer: The moon's orbit period in respect to the stars.

Item.heading: Eclipses
Item.Question: What are the two types of eclipses?
Item.Answer: Lunar Eclipse, Solar Eclipse

Item.heading: Eclipses
Item.Question: How do Lunar Eclipses happen?
Item.Answer: Moon passes through Earth's Shadow. It lasts 2-4 hours. Half of Earth appears to be night time. Only occurs during full moon.

Item.heading: Eclipses
Item.Question: How do Solar Eclipses happen?
Item.Answer: Moon passes between Sun and moon. It lasts 2-4 minutes. Seen by 1-2% of Earth. Moon is closer to the sun. Moon and sun have same Angular diameter: 1/2 degree. Can only occur during new moon.

Item.heading: Eclipses
Item.Question: How do we prove Earth is spherical?
Item.Answer: By observing multiple lunar eclipses.

Item.heading: Aristotle (384-322 B.C.)
Item.Question: What did Aristotle say about the universe? Was it wrong or right?
Item.Answer: There are 2 Realms in the universe: *Earth: things stand still, things change, chaos occurs. *Heavens: perpetual motion, things don't change, clockwork. *This was proven wrong.

Item.heading: Aristarchus (310-230 B.C.)
Item.Question: How much larger is the Earth than the moon in true size?
Item.Answer: Earth is 4x larger than moon in true size.

Item.heading: Aristarchus (310-230 B.C.)
Item.Question: True or False: The moon and sun have same apparent size.
Item.Answer: True: The moon and sun have same apparent size of 1/2 degree.

Item.heading: Aristarchus (310-230 B.C.)
Item.Question: How much further is the sun than the moon from the Earth?
Item.Answer: The sun is 400x further from the Earth than the moon.

Item.heading: Aristarchus (310-230 B.C.)
Item.Question: How much larger is the sun than the Earth in true size?
Item.Answer: The sun is 100x larger than the Earth in true size.

Item.heading: Small Angle Equation
Item.Question: What is the Small Angle Equation?
Item.Answer:
W = θd / 57.3
W: true diameter (true size) θ: Angular diameter (degree) or apparent size d: distance of object 57.3: conversion constant

Item.heading: Small Angle Equation
Item.Question: What are the proportions of the small angle equation factors.
Item.Answer: *If θ same, w & d are directly proportional w↑d↑. *If d same, θ & w are directly proportional θ↑w↑. *If w same, d & θ are inversely proportional d↑θ↓.

Item.heading: Scientific method
Item.Question: What are the steps of the scientific method?
Item.Answer: 1. Choose a topic to study 2. Collect all relevant data & facts (measurements & observations) 3. Formulate a theory to explain the data 4. Test theory's predictions against new observations

Item.heading: Scientific method
Item.Question: What should a proper theory do?
Item.Answer: . Explain all relevant data . make testable predictions . not invoke the supernatural

Item.heading: Scientific method
Item.Question: Can a theory be proven a hundred percent right? Why or why not?
Item.Answer: No because in order for a theory to be proven 100% correct, it would have to be tested in every possible condition.

Item.heading: Solar System Orbits
Item.Question: Which orbital model is correct, Copernicus or Ptolemy?
Item.Answer: Copernicus's orbital model is correct because it has the sun, not Earth, at the center with the planets orbiting it.

Item.heading: Solar System Orbits
Item.Question: In which planetary model is Venus and Mercury tied to the Sun's line-of-sight?
Item.Answer: In Ptolemy's model.

Item.heading: Solar System Orbits
Item.Question: "Geocentric" is another name for which plantery system (orbital) model?
Item.Answer: Geocentric is another name for Ptolemy's Earth-centered planetary system based off of Aristotle's thoughts on the universe.

Item.heading: Solar System Orbits
Item.Question: What fact proved that Ptolemy's planetary system orbital model does not work?
Item.Answer:
The phases of Venus show that Ptolemy's model does not work.
Ptolemy's model predicted a partial set of vissible phases for Venus. We now know this is false.

Item.heading: Solar System Orbits
Item.Question: In which planetary system orbital model(s) are stars on a fixed rotating sphere beyond the planets?
Item.Answer: In both Ptolemy's and Copernicus's model.

Item.heading: Solar System Orbits
Item.Question: In which planertary system orbital model are the planets rotating around the Sun?
Item.Answer: In Copernicus's model.

Item.heading: Solar System Orbits
Item.Question: Which planertary system orbital model predicts a full set of visible phases for Venus?
Item.Answer: Copernicus's model.

Item.heading: Celestial Motions
Item.Question: Why do star maps have east and west reversed?
Item.Answer: Because we look up at the sky.

Item.heading: Celestial Motions
Item.Question: In which direction do the sun and moon move across the sky each month?
Item.Answer: The sun and the moon move west to east across the sky each month.

Item.heading: Celestial Motions
Item.Question: Which planets move in "back and forth" motion centered on the sun?
Item.Answer: Mercury and Venus.

Item.heading: Celestial Motions
Item.Question: Mercury moves west to east across the sky? How often does it do so?
Item.Answer: Every two years.

Item.heading: Celestial Motions
Item.Question: How often and in which direction do Jupiter and Saturn move across the sky?
Item.Answer: Jupiter moves west to east across the sky every 12 years. Saturn moves west to east acorss the sky every 30 years.

Item.heading: Celestial Motions
Item.Question: Which planets show occasional illusions of retrograde loops in their movements across the sky?
Item.Answer: Jupiter, Mars, and Saturn.

Item.heading: Galileo
Item.Question: True or False: Galileo invented the telescope.
Item.Answer: False! Galileo did not event the telescope.

Item.heading: Galileo
Item.Question: What did Galileo do in 1609 to revolutionize astronomy?
Item.Answer: He built and used a telescope to observe the sky in 1609.

Item.heading: Galileo
Item.Question: What did Galileo observe with his telescope?
Item.Answer: . Sunspots come and go . Mountains on moons . The pahses of Venus . 4 million faint stars . 4 moons orbiting Jupiter

Item.heading: Tyko Brahe (1546 - 1601)
Item.Question: What two facts were Tyko Brahe most well known for?
Item.Answer: Tyko Brahe had the last, best naked-eye starmaps of his time. He also had the best planetary position tables.

Item.heading: Tyko Brahe (1546 - 1601)
Item.Question: Who did Tyko Brahe hire?
Item.Answer: Tyko Brahe hired J. Kepler, a mathematician.

Item.heading: J. Kepler (1571 - 1630)
Item.Question: What are Kepler's 3 laws of planetary motion?
Item.Answer:
K1. The planets move in ellipses with the sun at one focus.
K2. Equal Area - Equal Time: . Equal area is swept out in equal time by a line connecting a planet to the sun.
K3. The bigger the orbit size the larger the period. P^2 : A^3 for all planets: . The square of the orbital period (P) and the cube of the semi-major axis (A) are in a fixed ratio for all planets

Item.heading: J. Kepler (1571 - 1630)
Item.Question: What is Kepler's 1st law (K1) of planetary motion?
Item.Answer: The planets move in ellipses with the sun at the focus.

Item.heading: J. Kepler (1571 - 1630)
Item.Question: What is Kepler's 2nd law (K2) of planetary motion?
Item.Answer: Equal area is swept out in equal time by a line connecting a planet to the sun.

Item.heading: J. Kepler (1571 - 1630)
Item.Question: By Kepler's 2nd law of planetary motion (K2), where would planet speed be fastest, closer or further from the sun?
Item.Answer: Planet speed would be fastest when it is closer to the sun and slowest in the oppositie case.

Item.heading: J. Kepler (1571 - 1630)
Item.Question: By Kepler's 2nd law of planetary motion (K2), where would planets slow down?
Item.Answer: Planets would slow down as they get further away from the sun.

Item.Question: Melody
Item.Answer: The main tune, or "theme" in music

Item.Question: Rhythm
Item.Answer: The movement of music in time

Item.Question: Harmony
Item.Answer: Simultaneous combination of sounds
